Before traveling by plane with a baby, bare in mind that he/she have to be maximum as long as the bassinet and not more than 10 kg, approx 22. 5 lbs. The airline staff may deny you the bassinet due to obvious safety reasons. If you know the baby is bigger, I suggest you buy or bid for an extra seat to make the baby and you more comfortable during a long flight. Otherwise babies are just adorable and love to have them on my flights 😍

just a quick note. the bassinet is for babies under 25 pounds and not able to sit upright on their own. If you're traveling with an older/heavier baby they wont give you one :)

Dont check your carseats!!! The safest place for your baby on a plane is in their carseat. AND once you check a carseat it is considered no longer “accident free”. If you check your carseat it can get damaged during travel.

A trick I learned when my daughter was little and I couldn't dispose of a diaper right away, or was at a friends house.... quart freezer bags.
Flew with our 4 month old for 15 hours. No problems. It's much much easier to fly with an infant than with a baby who already knows how to walk or run.

Nice ! We took our 5 month old to NYC. We brought a stroller but never ended up using it. We learned it was way too difficult navigating the city with a clunky stroller. We used our Ergo baby carrier the whole time. If the parents and the baby are comfortable using that only, keep it minimal when you can, especially in dense metro areas where the culture and city aren't as accommodating to baby strollers!

You guys need to check out the stroller Jess uses on The Bucket List Family channel, it’s probably more for an older child, but it is an amazing folding with one hand contraption that is a must have for traveling with littles
Awesome to see what it’s like traveling with a baby - very helpful 😊

You just want to make sure you have how many hours worth of distractions packed in your hand luggage. Also keep in mind their attention span. My daughter focuses for about 5 mins on one activity so i packed 10 activities. If ipads work on yr kid, happy days

Oh my ....travelling with a 4 month old.  Easy peasy.  They only eat and sleep.  The constant motion and white noise makes them sleep really well.  Try travelling with a toddler.  That’s a different kettle of fish.  I’m hungry.  I’m not hungry. I’m thirsty.  I’m tired.  I’m not tired.  I want to go for a walk.  I wanna watch a movie.  I don’t like any of those movies.  I forgot my favourite doll at home.  I need to have it NOW.  SCREAM!!!!!  I need to go to the toilet and I will touch every filthy, infected item in my path.  No, I don’t want to wash my hands.  No, I won’t brush my teeth.  Yes, I want candy and I will throw a tantrum unless you give it to me right now.    SCREAM!!!  I’m gonna kick the back of this seat.  Kick.  Kick.   Kick.   Kick.  Kick.   Kick.   Oooh.....chocolate.   Yes!    I need to go to the toilet.  SCREAM!!!  Kick.  Kick.   Kick.  Good luck!

Or if suitcase got lost and diaper bag was forgotten somehow then at least one of our bags will still have the necessary things.

I've travelled on a plane once with a baby behind me... It was a 14 hour ride from Toronto to Tokyo. Never.. again.. will I fly without knowing. I understand your feelings. Once, I flew to Europe on a business class with my husband and then 14 months daughter, there was a toddler who was crying for 6 hours, I saw that his mother was exhausted caring for his infant brother, and all her efforts to calm the toddler failed. His father was sleeping the entire time.
I was exhausted listening to his non-stop cry. I was able to share with him some of my daughter's toys, and coloring books and eventually he was interested in coloring and he stopped crying.
After 1 hour, the flight crew had to ask if there was a doctor on our flight, the boy's father woke up to attend to the medical emergency. When he returned back to his seat, he thanked me for helping with his son and told me that he had to perform an emergency surgery that lasted more than 12 hours.
From that moment I realized that we don't know what's going on with our fellow travelers with children. If I can help I will.

Girl, I absolutely understand you. I flew from the Caribbean to Europe in 2011. A baby sat next to me. That was horrible. 😣😣😣😣😣 That was the most horrible flight EVER. Some airlines need reminding that you will need the pushchair when you get off the plain, I traveled with my daughter a few months after a c-section that causes complications and ended up having to carry her around 1.5 miles with blood coming out of my tummy. If you need your pushchair one way to make sure you get it or a wheelchair is to stay on the plain until they sort it out and also tell crew before take of and landing that you need it as you get off the plain

I flew with my then 8 month old on a 13 hr flight from Seattle Wa to Korea. We were in the same type of seat with the bassinet attached to the wall. It was one of the most comfortable flights I have ever taken with my children. Being a military family we flew quite often and I also used to fly not only with my kids but my Pomeranian in a carrier as well. The more you do the easier it gets!

@Kaitlyn my child is now 22 yrs old and car seats werent required on flights with children under 2 who were lap riders. I think its still the same. Im sure you have never traveled with kids. Were you able to put your beastmilk in their fridge or get ice? We are flying with our son in April for the first time and he will be almost 4 months as well!
Depends what airline and aircraft you fly with. My airline doesn't have a fridge or microwave on board.

Also not every aircraft has a chiller and at my airline we don’t on all our aircraft and are not allowed to accept other people’s items to keep cold (for so may logistical and safety reasons) , but we can and will give you some ice.
The airline put my milk in the fridge. Then they also warmed it up when I needed it. They just put the bottle in a cup of hot water.
